Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of Small-scale Heterogeneity in the Deep Earth
Award.AbstractNarration:
Little is known about three-dimensional structures in the deep earth whose size is less than 100 km. These small-scale deep structures are important to understanding the historical and future evolution of earth's composition and its surface tectonics. They affect the shapes and amplitudes of seismic waves used to forecast the size of earthquake ground motions and to predict the differences between the seismic signatures of earthquakes and underground nuclear tests. Such small-scale structures cannot be imaged by conventiional seismic tomography, which processes travel times of seismic waves with methods similar to medical CAT scanning. Instead, this project employs a technique using seiismic recordings by many, closely spaced, seismometers to retrieve a characterisitic spectrum of scale lengths of small-scale structures. This specturm constrains the sizes, shapes, and composition of the heterogeneities. The project also trains graduate students in seismic data retrieval, processing, imaging, and computer programming. These are skills important in resource exploration and remediation of contaminated groundwater. Results will be incorporated in undergraduate courses in the physical sciences to enhance recruitment and training in both academic and industrial applications of geophysical research.



The characterization of small-scale heterogeneity (<100 km) is important to understand the surface sampling of Earth's mantle chemistry and the time history and nature of chemical mixing controlled by convection and plate tectonics. Directionally dependent scattering of seismic waves by small-scale heterogeneity can affect estimates of viscoelastic attenuation and anisotropy, which in turn are important for estimating temperature, mineral composition, and mineral phase. Amplitude and phase coherences of body waves recorded by dense arrays of seismic stations will be inverted to image statistical realizations of small-scale heterogeneity. This process of stochastic tomography will determine the characteristic lenth scales and seismic velocity perturbatons of the small-scale chemical and thermal heterogeneity of the earth that cannot be resolved by conventional tomography. The resullts will and test fundamental assumptions of convective miixing predicted from geodynamic models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chemical composition, temperature, and crystalline structure  of Earth's interior is three-dimensional.  The timing of seismic waves have revealed its average vertical structure, and the expansion of seismic sensors at its surface have made possible 3-D images of its interior by exploiting algorithms used in medical tomography.  The images obtained by traditional tomography, however, do not fully exploit additional seismic observations that can further constrain smaller scale 3-D structure.  These smaller scale-structures, about  the size of the wavelength of the seismic waves, focus and defocus the amplitude of the waves and change their arrival time at closely spaced seismic sensors. Detection and the mapping of these small-scale structures are important for estimating, tempearture, mineral composisiton, and crystalline structure of the Earth and their relation to the slow fluid-like motion of its interior that drive surface tectonic features exhibited in earthquakes and volcanoes.

By measuring the fluctuations in amplitude and travel times of seismic waves at the closely spaced seismic sensors of  NSF's Earthscope array, we implemented a new algorithm that makes it possible to describe the depth variation of small-scale chemical and temperature fluctuations to a depth of 1000 km. We have verified that these fluctuations in chemistry, temperature and pressure all act together to produce the strongest changes in seismic velocity in relatively narrow depth intervals.  These depth intervals agree well with the predictions of the depths in which atoms comprising the crystalline structure of Earth's mantle rearrange themselves into denser structures, which have been termed solid-solid phase changes. The algorihm making this discovery possible, called stochastic tomography, can be applied to detect new regions of chemical variation in the deep Earth that have been affected by the history of deep mantle circulation and the cycling of surface tectonic plates.

The spatial spectrum of small-scale chemical heterogeneity of Earth determined by this project is also important to estimating precise earthquake locations for nuclear test monitoring and estimation of the hazards of earthquake gound motion.This project included education and training in seismic data retrieval, proscessing, wavefield modeling, parallel computing, and structural imaging for a graduate student. Training of undergraduate students in seismic data retrieval and processing was provided in the form of special topic and independent study projects. Research results were incorporated in large undergraduate introductory courses in general physics to encourage recruitment of students in areas of geophysical research.
